entities.title: Knights of Columbus
entities.description: The Knights of Columbus is a global Catholic fraternal service order founded by Michael J. McGivney on March 29, 1882. Membership is composed of practicing Catholic men. It is led by Supreme Knight Patrick E. Kelly, the order's 14th Supreme Knight.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sarah Childress Polk, First Lady of the United States (b. 1803)

entities.title: Sarah Childress Polk
entities.description: Sarah Polk was the First Lady of the United States from 1845 to 1849. She was the wife of the 11th President of the United States, James K. Polk.

heading: Deaths
txt: Simeon Solomon, English soldier and painter (b. 1840)

entities.title: Simeon Solomon
entities.description:
Simeon Solomon was a British painter associated with the Pre-Raphaelites who was noted for his depictions of Jewish life and same-sex desire. 
His career was cut short as a result of public scandal following his arrests and convictions for attempt sodomy in 1873 and 1874.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Stanley, British engineer and author (b. 1829)

entities.title: William Stanley (inventor)
entities.description: William Ford Robinson Stanley was a British inventor with 78 patents filed in both the United Kingdom and the United States of America. He was an engineer who designed and made precision drawing and mathematical instruments, as well as surveying instruments and telescopes, manufactured by his company "William Ford Stanley and Co. Ltd."

heading: Deaths
txt: Rebecca Cole, American physician and social reformer (b. 1846)

entities.title: Rebecca Cole
entities.description: Rebecca J. Cole was an American physician, organization founder and social reformer. In 1867, she became the second African-American woman to become a doctor in the United States after Rebecca Lee Crumpler's achievement three years earlier.

heading: Deaths
txt: Klabund, German author and poet (b. 1890)

entities.title: Klabund
entities.description: Alfred Henschke, better known by his pseudonym Klabund, was a German writer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hugh Trumble, Australian cricketer and accountant (b. 1876)

entities.title: Hugh Trumble
entities.description: Hugh Trumble was an Australian cricketer who played 32 Test matches as a bowling all-rounder between 1890 and 1904. He captained the Australian team in two Tests, winning both. Trumble took 141 wickets in Test cricket—a world record at the time of his retirement—at an average of 21.78 runs per wicket. He is one of only four bowlers to twice take a hat-trick in Test cricket. Observers in Trumble's

heading: Deaths
txt: Maximilian Kolbe, Polish martyr and saint (b. 1894)

entities.title: Maximilian Kolbe
entities.description: Maximilian Maria Kolbe, venerated as Saint Maximilian Kolbe, was a Polish Catholic priest and Conventual Franciscan friar who volunteered to die in place of a stranger in the German death camp of Auschwitz, located in German-occupied Poland during World War II. He had been active in promoting the veneration of the Immaculate Virgin Mary, founding and supervising the monastery of Niepokalanów near

heading: Deaths
txt: Paul Sabatier, French chemist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1854)

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry is awarded annually by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences to scientists in the various fields of chemistry. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895, awarded for outstanding contributions in chemistry, physics, literature, peace, and physiology or medicine. This award is administered by the Nobel Foundation, and awarded by t

heading: Deaths
txt: Joe Kelley, American baseball player and manager (b. 1871)

entities.title: Joe Kelley
entities.description: Joseph James Kelley was an American left fielder in Major League Baseball (MLB) who starred in the outfield of the Baltimore Orioles teams of the 1890s. Making up the nucleus of the Orioles along with John McGraw, Willie Keeler, and Hughie Jennings, Kelley received the nickname "Kingpin of the Orioles".

heading: Deaths
txt: William Randolph Hearst, American publisher and politician, founded the Hearst Corporation (b. 1863)

entities.title: William Randolph Hearst
entities.description: William Randolph Hearst Sr. was an American businessman, newspaper publisher, and politician known for developing the nation's largest newspaper chain and media company, Hearst Communications. His flamboyant methods of yellow journalism influenced the nation's popular media by emphasizing sensationalism and human interest stories. Hearst entered the publishing business in 1887 with Mitchell Trubit

entities.title: Hearst Corporation
entities.description: Hearst Communications, Inc., often referred to simply as Hearst, is an American multinational mass media and business information conglomerate based in the Hearst Tower in Midtown Manhattan, New York City.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hugo Eckener, German pilot and designer (b. 1868)

entities.title: Hugo Eckener
entities.description: Hugo Eckener was the manager of the Luftschiffbau Zeppelin during the inter-war years, and also the commander of the famous Graf Zeppelin for most of its record-setting flights, including the first airship flight around the world, making him the most successful airship commander in history. He was also responsible for the construction of the most successful type of airships of all time. An anti-Na

heading: Deaths
txt: Herbert Putnam, American lawyer and publisher, Librarian of Congress (b. 1861)

entities.title: Herbert Putnam
entities.description: George Herbert Putnam was an American librarian. He was the eighth Librarian of Congress from 1899 to 1939. He implemented his vision of a universal collection with strengths in many languages, especially from Europe and Latin America.

entities.title: Librarian of Congress
entities.description: The librarian of Congress is the head of the Library of Congress, appointed by the president of the United States with the advice and consent of the United States Senate, for a term of ten years. The librarian of Congress appoints the U.S. poet laureate and awards the Gershwin Prize for Popular Song.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bertolt Brecht, German poet, playwright, and director (b. 1898)

entities.title: Bertolt Brecht
entities.description: Eugen Berthold Friedrich Brecht, known professionally as Bertolt Brecht, was a German theatre practitioner, playwright, and poet. Coming of age during the Weimar Republic, he had his first successes as a playwright in Munich and moved to Berlin in 1924, where he wrote The Threepenny Opera with Kurt Weill and began a lifelong collaboration with the composer Hanns Eisler. Immersed in Marxist thought

heading: Deaths
txt: Konstantin von Neurath, German lawyer and politician, Reich Minister of Foreign Affairs (b. 1873)

entities.title: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Germany)
entities.description: The Federal Minister for Foreign Affairs is the head of the Federal Foreign Office and a member of the Cabinet of Germany. The current office holder is Heiko Maas. Since 1966, the Foreign Minister has often also simultaneously held the office of Vice Chancellor.

heading: Deaths
txt: Frédéric Joliot-Curie, French physicist and chemist, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1900)

entities.title: Frédéric Joliot-Curie
entities.description: Jean Frédéric Joliot-Curie was a French physicist and husband of Irène Joliot-Curie, with whom he was jointly awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1935 for their discovery of artificial radioactivity. Joliot-Curie and his wife also founded the Orsay Faculty of Sciences, part of the Paris-Saclay University.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry is awarded annually by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences to scientists in the various fields of chemistry. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895, awarded for outstanding contributions in chemistry, physics, literature, peace, and physiology or medicine. This award is administered by the Nobel Foundation, and awarded by t

heading: Deaths
txt: Clifford Odets, American director, playwright, and screenwriter (b. 1906)

entities.title: Clifford Odets
entities.description: Clifford Odets was an American playwright, screenwriter, and director. In the mid-1930s he was widely seen as the potential successor to Nobel Prize-winning playwright Eugene O'Neill, as O'Neill began to withdraw from Broadway's commercial pressures and increasing critical backlash. From January 1935 Odets' socially relevant dramas were extremely influential, particularly for the remainder of the

heading: Deaths
txt: Johnny Burnette, American singer-songwriter (b. 1934)

entities.title: Johnny Burnette
entities.description: John Joseph Burnette was an American singer-songwriter of rockabilly and pop music. In 1952, he and his brother, Dorsey Burnette, and their friend Paul Burlison formed the band that became known as the Rock and Roll Trio. His career was cut short on August 14, 1964, when he was killed in a boat crash at age 30.

heading: Deaths
txt: Vello Kaaristo, Estonian skier (b. 1911)

entities.title: Vello Kaaristo
entities.description: Vello Kaaristo was the first Estonian cross-country skier to compete in the Olympics. At the 1936 Winter Olympics in Garmisch-Partenkirchen he placed 30th in the 18 km event with the time of 1'25:11, and 23rd in the 50 km event with the time of 4'02:52.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bob Anderson, English motorcycle racer and race car driver (b. 1931)

entities.title: Bob Anderson (racing driver)
entities.description: Robert Hugh Fearon Anderson was a British Grand Prix motorcycle road racer and racing driver. He competed in Grand Prix motorcycle racing from 1958 to 1960 and in Formula One from 1963 to the 1967 seasons. He was also a two-time winner of the North West 200 race in Northern Ireland. Anderson was one of the last independent privateer drivers in Formula One before escalating costs made it impossible

heading: Deaths
txt: Oscar Levant, American actor, pianist, and composer (b. 1906)

entities.title: Oscar Levant
entities.description: Oscar Levant was an American concert pianist, composer, music conductor, author, radio game show panelist, television talk show host, comedian and actor. Though awarded a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame for recordings featuring his piano performances, he was as famous for his mordant character and witticisms, on the radio and later in movies and television, as for his music.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jules Romains, French author and poet (b. 1885)

heading: Deaths
txt: Fred Gipson, American journalist and author (b. 1908)

entities.title: Fred Gipson
entities.description: Frederick Benjamin "Fred" Gipson was an American author. He is best known for writing the 1956 novel Old Yeller, which became a popular 1957 Walt Disney film. Gipson was born on a farm near Mason in the Texas Hill Country, the son of Beck Gipson and Emma Deishler. After working at a variety of farming and ranching jobs, he enrolled in 1933 at the University of Texas at Austin. There he wrote for t

heading: Deaths
txt: Nicolas Bentley, English author and illustrator (b. 1907)

entities.title: Nicolas Bentley
entities.description: Nicolas Clerihew Bentley was a British author and illustrator, best known for his humorous cartoon drawings in books and magazines in the 1930s and 1940s. The son of Edmund Clerihew Bentley, he was given the name Nicholas, but opted to change the spelling.

heading: Deaths
txt: Dorothy Stratten, Canadian-American model and actress (b. 1960)

entities.title: Dorothy Stratten
entities.description: Dorothy Ruth Hoogstraten, known professionally as Dorothy Stratten, was a Canadian Playboy Playmate, model, and actress. Stratten was the Playboy Playmate of the Month for August 1979 and Playmate of the Year in 1980. Stratten appeared in three comedy films and in at least two episodes of shows broadcast on US network television. She was murdered at the age of 20 by her estranged husband and manag

heading: Deaths
txt: Karl Böhm, Austrian conductor and director (b. 1894)

entities.title: Karl Böhm
entities.description: Karl August Leopold Böhm was an Austrian conductor. He was best known for his performances of the music of Mozart, Wagner and Richard Strauss.

heading: Deaths
txt: Dudley Nourse, South African cricketer (b. 1910)

heading: Deaths
txt: Mahasi Sayadaw, Burmese monk and philosopher (b. 1904)

entities.title: Mahasi Sayadaw
entities.description: Mahāsī Sayādaw U Sobhana was a Burmese Theravada Buddhist monk and meditation master who had a significant impact on the teaching of vipassanā (insight) meditation in the West and throughout Asia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Spud Davis, American baseball player, coach, and manager (b. 1904)

entities.title: Spud Davis
entities.description: Virgil Lawrence "Spud" Davis was an American professional baseball player, coach, scout and manager. He played in Major League Baseball as a catcher for the St. Louis Cardinals, Philadelphia Phillies, Cincinnati Reds, and Pittsburgh Pirates. Davis' .308 career batting average ranks fourth all-time among major league catchers.

heading: Deaths
txt: J. B. Priestley, English novelist and playwright (b. 1894)

heading: Deaths
txt: Gale Sondergaard, American actress (b. 1899)

entities.title: Gale Sondergaard
entities.description: Gale Sondergaard was an American actress.

heading: Deaths
txt: Roy Buchanan, American singer-songwriter and guitarist (b. 1939)

entities.title: Roy Buchanan
entities.description: Leroy "Roy" Buchanan was an American guitarist and blues musician. A pioneer of the Telecaster sound, Buchanan worked as a sideman and as a solo artist, with two gold albums early in his career and two later solo albums that made it to the Billboard chart. He never achieved stardom, but he is still considered a highly influential guitar player. Guitar Player praised him as having one of the "50 Gr

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Calvert, South African-English singer-songwriter and playwright (b. 1945)

heading: Deaths
txt: Enzo Ferrari, Italian race car driver and businessman, founded Ferrari (b. 1898)

entities.title: Ferrari
entities.description: Ferrari S.p.A. is an Italian luxury sports car manufacturer based in Maranello, Italy. Founded by Enzo Ferrari in 1939 out of the Alfa Romeo race division as Auto Avio Costruzioni, the company built its first car in 1940, and produced its first Ferrari-badged car in 1947.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alberto Crespo, Argentinian race car driver (b. 1920)

entities.title: Alberto Crespo
entities.description: Alberto Augusto Crespo was a racing driver from Buenos Aires, Argentina. He entered one World Championship Formula One Grand Prix, the 1952 Italian Grand Prix, with a Maserati entered for him by Enrico Platé. Crespo narrowly failed to qualify.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Sirica, American lawyer and judge (b. 1904)

entities.title: John Sirica
entities.description: John Joseph Sirica was a United States district judge of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, where he became famous for his role in the trials stemming from the Watergate scandal.

heading: Deaths
txt: Elias Canetti, Bulgarian-Swiss author, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1905)

entities.title: Elias Canetti
entities.description: Elias Canetti was a German-language author, born in Ruse, Bulgaria to a merchant family. They moved to Manchester, England, but his father died in 1912, and his mother took her three sons back to the continent. They settled in Vienna.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Literature
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Literature is a Swedish literature prize that is awarded annually, since 1901, to an author from any country who has, in the words of the will of Swedish industrialist Alfred Nobel, "in the field of literature, produced the most outstanding work in an idealistic direction". Though individual works are sometimes cited as being particularly noteworthy, the award is based on an aut

heading: Deaths
txt: Alice Childress, American actress, playwright, and author (b. 1912)

heading: Deaths
txt: Sergiu Celibidache, Romanian conductor and composer (b. 1912)

entities.title: Sergiu Celibidache
entities.description: Sergiu Celibidache was a Romanian conductor, composer, musical theorist, and teacher. Educated in his native Romania, and later in Paris and Berlin, Celibidache's career in music spanned over five decades, including tenures as principal conductor of the Munich Philharmonic, Berlin Philharmonic, Sicilian Symphony Orchestra and several other European orchestras. Later in life, he taught at Mainz Uni

heading: Deaths
txt: Pee Wee Reese, American baseball player and sportscaster (b. 1918)

entities.title: Pee Wee Reese
entities.description: Harold Peter Henry "Pee Wee" Reese was an American professional baseball player. He played in Major League Baseball as a shortstop for the Brooklyn and Los Angeles Dodgers from 1940 to 1958. A ten-time All Star, Reese contributed to seven National League championships for the Dodgers and was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1984. Reese is also famous for his support of his teammate Jacki

heading: Deaths
txt: Larry Rivers, American painter and sculptor (b. 1923)

entities.title: Larry Rivers
entities.description: Larry Rivers was an American artist, musician, filmmaker and occasional actor. Rivers resided and maintained studios in New York City, Southampton, Long Island, and Zihuatanejo, Mexico.

heading: Deaths
txt: Helmut Rahn, German footballer (b. 1929)

entities.title: Helmut Rahn
entities.description: Helmut Rahn, known as Der Boss, was a German footballer who played as a forward. He became a legend for having scored the winning goal in the final of the 1954 FIFA World Cup.

heading: Deaths
txt: Czesław Miłosz, Polish-born American novelist, essayist, and poet, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1911)

entities.title: Czesław Miłosz
entities.description: Czesław Miłosz was a Polish-American poet, prose writer, translator, and diplomat. Regarded as one of the great poets of the 20th century, he won the 1980 Nobel Prize in Literature. In its citation, the Swedish Academy called Miłosz a writer who "voices man's exposed condition in a world of severe conflicts".

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Literature
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Literature is a Swedish literature prize that is awarded annually, since 1901, to an author from any country who has, in the words of the will of Swedish industrialist Alfred Nobel, "in the field of literature, produced the most outstanding work in an idealistic direction". Though individual works are sometimes cited as being particularly noteworthy, the award is based on an aut

heading: Deaths
txt: Trevor Skeet, New Zealand-English lawyer and politician (b. 1918)

heading: Deaths
txt: Bruno Kirby, American actor (b. 1949)

entities.title: Bruno Kirby
entities.description: Bruno Kirby was an American actor, singer, voice artist, and comedian. He was known for his roles in City Slickers, When Harry Met Sally..., Good Morning, Vietnam, The Godfather Part II, and Donnie Brasco. He voiced Reginald Stout in Stuart Little.

heading: Deaths
txt: Tikhon Khrennikov, Russian pianist and composer (b. 1913)

entities.title: Tikhon Khrennikov
entities.description: Tikhon Nikolayevich Khrennikov was a Russian and Soviet composer, pianist, and leader of the Union of Soviet Composers, who was also known for his political activities. He wrote three symphonies, four piano concertos, two violin concertos, two cello concertos, operas, operettas, ballets, chamber music, incidental music and film music.

heading: Deaths
txt: Herman Leonard, American photographer (b. 1923)

entities.title: Herman Leonard
entities.description: Herman Leonard was an American photographer known for his unique images of jazz icons.

heading: Deaths
txt: Vilasrao Deshmukh, Indian lawyer and politician, Chief Minister of Maharashtra (b. 1945)

entities.title: Vilasrao Deshmukh
entities.description: Vilasrao Dagadojirao Deshmukh was an Indian politician who served two terms as the Chief Minister of the state of Maharashtra. He also served in the Union cabinet as the Minister of Science and Technology and Minister of Earth Sciences.

entities.title: Chief Minister of Maharashtra
entities.description: The Chief Minister of Maharashtra is the head of the Government of the Indian state of Maharashtra. Following elections to the Legislative Assembly, the Governor invites the party with a majority of seats to form the government and appoints the Chief Minister (CM). If the appointee is not a member of either the Legislative Assembly or the Legislative Council of Maharashtra, then the Constitution s

heading: Deaths
txt: Svetozar Gligorić, Serbian chess player (b. 1923)

heading: Deaths
txt: Phyllis Thaxter, American actress (b. 1919)

heading: Deaths
txt: Jack Germond, American journalist and author (b. 1928)

entities.title: Jack Germond
entities.description: John Worthen Germond, known as Jack Germond, was an American journalist, author, and pundit. His journalistic career spanned over 50 years; Germond wrote for the Washington Star and The Baltimore Sun. Together with Jules Witcover, Germond co-wrote "Politics Today", a five-day-a-week syndicated column, for almost a quarter-century.

heading: Deaths
txt: Leonard Fein, American journalist and academic, co-founded Moment Magazine (b. 1934)

entities.title: Leonard Fein
entities.description: Leonard J. Fein, also known as Leibel Fein, was an American activist, writer, and teacher specializing in Jewish social themes.

heading: Deaths
txt: George V. Hansen, American politician (b. 1930)

heading: Deaths
txt: Bob Johnston, American songwriter and producer (b. 1932)

entities.title: Bob Johnston
entities.description: Donald William 'Bob' Johnston was an American record producer, best known for his work with Bob Dylan, Johnny Cash, Leonard Cohen, and Simon & Garfunkel.

heading: Deaths
txt: Fyvush Finkel, American actor (b. 1922)

entities.title: Fyvush Finkel
entities.description: Philip "Fyvush" Finkel was an American actor known as a star of Yiddish theater and for his role as lawyer Douglas Wambaugh on the television series Picket Fences, for which he earned an Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series in 1994. He is also known for his portrayal of Harvey Lipschultz, a crotchety history teacher, on the television series Boston Public.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jill Janus, American singer (b. 1975)

entities.title: Jill Janus
entities.description: Jill Janiszewski was the lead singer of American heavy metal bands Huntress, The Starbreakers and Chelsea Girls.

heading: Deaths
txt: Polly Farmer, Australian footballer and coach (b. 1935)

entities.title: Polly Farmer
entities.description: Graham Vivian "Polly" Farmer was an Australian rules football player and coach who revolutionised ruckwork and handballing.

heading: Deaths
txt: James R. Thompson, American politician, Governor of Illinois (1977-91) (b. 1936)

entities.title: James R. Thompson
entities.description: James Robert Thompson Jr., also known as Big Jim Thompson, was the 37th and longest-serving governor of the US state of Illinois, serving from 1977 to 1991. A moderate Republican who sometimes took more liberal stances on issues, Thompson was elected to four consecutive terms and held the office for 14 years. Many years after leaving public office, he served as a member of the National Commission

heading: Deaths
txt: Julian Bream, English classical guitarist and lutenist (b. 1933)

heading: Deaths
txt: Angela Buxton, British tennis player (b. 1934)
